head.title: California Adopts First Phase of Ocean Preserves

hedline.hl1: California Adopts First Phase of Ocean Preserves
hedline.hl2: California Adopts First Phase of Ocean Preserves

abstract.p: California Fish and Game Commission adopts plan to create statewide system of connected ocean preserves where fishing and other human activities would be limited or banned; first phase sets aside waters along 200-mile stretch of coast between Point Conception near Santa Barbara and Half Moon Bay south of San Francisco (M)

block.p: California wildlife regulators adopted a sweeping ocean protection plan on Friday, the first such statewide effort in the country, intended to establish a network of underwater refuges.

The plan, unanimously approved by members of the California Fish and Game Commission, will create a statewide system of connected ocean preserves where fishing and other human activities would be limited or banned.
A plan approved by wildlife regulators will create a statewide system of protected areas where fishing and other human activities would be limited or banned.
California wildlife regulators adopted a sweeping ocean protection plan on Friday, the first such statewide effort in the country, intended to establish a network of underwater refuges.

The plan, unanimously approved by members of the California Fish and Game Commission, will create a statewide system of connected ocean preserves where fishing and other human activities would be limited or banned.

The first phase sets aside the waters along a 200-mile stretch of the coast, including tidal areas that fan out three miles from shore, to protect marine habitat between Point Conception, near Santa Barbara, and Half Moon Bay, about 25 miles south of here.

Environmental advocates hailed the vote, with the Natural Resources Defense Council calling the approved plan a ''balanced compromise using high quality science.'' But commercial fishermen say the plan does little more than further restrict their industry.

''Just protecting part of the ocean won't work,'' said Zeke Grader, executive director of the Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations. ''We can't just restrict fishermen. We need to address pollution and acidification of the oceans.''
The effort to create the preserves stems from legislation passed in 1999, when Gray Davis, then the governor, signed the California Marine Life Protection Act.

The new law required the state to establish fully protected ocean areas, ultimately along its entire coast, to help replenish dwindling fisheries, conserve biological diversity and protect habitats that scientists say have been ravaged by over-fishing and chemical contamination.

''These ocean areas are our underwater Yosemites,'' said Kate Wing, a policy analyst with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group that supports the effort. ''To me, this is saving for our collective retirement, putting aside and investing now so there will be a payoff 20 to 50 years down the road.''

The first phase of the plan approved Friday designates 29 offshore areas for protection beginning as early as July. The entire protected area between Point Conception and Half Moon Bay would cover 1,150 square miles and offer some type of protective status to nearly 20 percent of the state's waters off the Central Coast.
Of the overall area, 8 percent, or 13 of the 29 offshore areas, would be completely protected, forbidding all human activity. The remaining waters would allow limited sport and commercial fishing.

Regulators have said the protection plan is scheduled for completion by 2011. The next phase sets aside underwater ocean refuges that extend beyond Half Moon Bay and stretch to Point Arena, about 100 miles north of San Francisco.
